sub_topic: Prove that every group of prime order is cyclic.
message_1: What is the generator of a group of prime order 17?
message_2:
A generator of a group of prime order p (in this case, p=17) is an element g in the group such that its powers generate all the other elements in the group. In other words, g has order p.

For a cyclic group of prime order 17, we can consider the multiplicative group of integers modulo 17, denoted as (Z/17Z)*. This group has 16 elements: {1, 2, 3, ..., 16}. To find a generator, we need to find an element g in this group such that g^i (mod 17) generates all the non-zero elements of the group.

By trying different elements, we can find that g=3 is a generator of the group:

3^1 ≡ 3 (mod 17)
3^2 ≡ 9 (mod 17)
3^3 ≡ 10 (mod 17)
3^4 ≡ 13 (mod 17)
3^5 ≡ 5 (mod 17)
3^6 ≡ 15 (mod 17)
3^7 ≡ 11 (mod 17)
3^8 ≡ 16 (mod 17)
3^9 ≡ 14 (mod 17)
3^10 ≡ 8 (mod 17)
3^11 ≡ 7 (mod 17)
3^12 ≡ 4 (mod 17)
3^13 ≡ 12 (mod 17)
3^14 ≡ 2 (mod 17)
3^15 ≡ 6 (mod 17)
3^16 ≡ 1 (mod 17)

As we can see, the powers of 3 generate all the non-zero elements of the group (Z/17Z)*, so 3 is a generator of the group of prime order 17.
